title: Creator Economy Power Law
context: The creator economy narrative is seductive: anyone can build an audience, monetize their passion, and escape the 9-to-5. Platforms like YouTube, TikTok, Substack, and Patreon have enabled over 200 million people globally to identify as content creators. But the economics follow a brutal power law distribution that mirrors — and in many cases exceeds — the inequality of traditional employment. The top 1% of creators capture over 90% of total revenue. The median creator earns less than $500/year. Most never earn enough to cover the tools and time they invest. The platforms benefit regardless: every creator, profitable or not, generates content that drives engagement and ad revenue. The creator economy didn't democratize wealth creation — it created a new class of unpaid content laborers who subsidize platform valuations with their free work.
hypothesis: The creator economy democratizes income and lets everyone monetize their passion.

dontIf: You're quitting stable employment to become a full-time creator without 12+ months of runway

ifYouMust: Treat content creation as a side project until revenue exceeds 50% of your living expenses for 6+ months
Build an email list or owned audience channel from day one — don't rely solely on platform distribution
Diversify revenue across multiple platforms and income types (ads, sponsorships, products, services)
Set a clear financial threshold and timeline — if not met, reassess without sunk cost fallacy
